key_points: Australia has passed a law requiring Facebook and Google to pay for local news content.
The law, known as the News Media and Digital Platforms Mandatory Bargaining Code, aims to support public interest journalism.
Treasurer Josh Frydenberg and Communications Minister Paul Fletcher announced the law and its aim to ensure fair remuneration for news media.
Both Google and Facebook initially resisted the law, fearing it could set a precedent worldwide.
An appointed arbitrator will decide the payment amount if no commercial deal is reached.
Facebook will restore news pages in Australia, reversing a previous decision to block news in response to the proposed law.
Facebook and Google have both made commercial agreements with Australian media businesses.
The law will be reviewed by the Treasury within one year of its commencement.
Experts view the final law changes as a compromise mainly benefiting Facebook.
Australia's competition watchdog and Facebook claimed victory after the law's amendments.
spokespersons: Campbell Brown (Vice President for Global News Partnerships, Facebook)
Nick Clegg (Vice President for Global Affairs, Facebook)
Johan Lidberg (Associate Professor of Journalism, Monash University)
